claim: Vitamin D supplementation reduces the risk of respiratory infections.
abstract: Background: Vitamin D has immunomodulatory effects that may protect against respiratory infections. Methods: We conducted a meta-analysis of 25 randomized controlled trials including 11,321 participants. Results: Vitamin D supplementation reduced the risk of acute respiratory infection (OR 0.88, 95% CI 0.81-0.96). The protective effect was strongest in participants with baseline vitamin D deficiency. Conclusion: Vitamin D supplementation is safe and provides modest protection against respiratory infections.

claim: Coffee consumption increases the risk of cardiovascular disease.
abstract: Objective: To examine the association between coffee consumption and cardiovascular disease risk. Methods: Prospective cohort study of 468,629 UK Biobank participants followed for 11 years. Results: Compared to non-coffee drinkers, moderate coffee consumption (3-4 cups/day) was associated with lower risk of cardiovascular disease (HR 0.85, 95% CI 0.79-0.92). Heavy consumption (>6 cups/day) showed no significant association. Conclusion: Moderate coffee consumption is associated with reduced cardiovascular risk.

Purpose: To evaluate the effects of exercise on depression symptoms. Methods: Systematic review of 35 RCTs comparing exercise interventions to control conditions in adults with depression. Results: Exercise significantly reduced depression symptoms (SMD -0.66, 95% CI -0.86 to -0.46). Effects were similar for aerobic and resistance training. Higher intensity exercise showed larger effects. Limitations: High heterogeneity and risk of bias in some studies. Conclusion: Exercise is an effective intervention for depression.

claim: Artificial sweeteners help with weight loss.
abstract: Background: Artificial sweeteners are widely used as sugar substitutes for weight management. Methods: We conducted a randomized trial of 200 overweight adults assigned to beverages with sugar, artificial sweeteners, or water for 12 weeks. Results: The artificial sweetener group showed no significant difference in weight change compared to the sugar group (-0.2 kg vs -0.3 kg, p=0.78). Only the water group showed significant weight loss (-1.8 kg). Conclusion: Replacing sugar with artificial sweeteners did not result in weight loss in this trial.

Aim: To assess probiotic efficacy in preventing antibiotic-associated diarrhea. Methods: Meta-analysis of 42 RCTs with 11,811 participants receiving antibiotics with or without probiotic co-administration. Results: Probiotic supplementation significantly reduced the risk of antibiotic-associated diarrhea (RR 0.58, 95% CI 0.50-0.68, NNT=13). Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG and Saccharomyces boulardii showed the strongest evidence. Adverse events were rare. Conclusion: Probiotics are effective for preventing antibiotic-associated diarrhea.

claim: Mediterranean diet reduces Alzheimer's disease risk.
abstract: Introduction: Diet may influence dementia risk through multiple mechanisms. Methods: We examined Mediterranean diet adherence and brain volumes in 512 participants from the Lothian Birth Cohort. Results: Higher Mediterranean diet scores were associated with less total brain atrophy over 3 years (Î²=0.12, p=0.04). The association was attenuated after controlling for education and social class. No association was found with specific regional volumes or cognitive decline. Conclusion: Mediterranean diet may protect against general brain atrophy, though confounding cannot be ruled out.
